Thunderbolt hits non-Volt Absorb Corviknight and Manaphy, Ice Beam threatens Great Tusk and Dragonite, and Draco Meteor is a strong STAB move that can OHKO Latios and does significant damage to Roaring Moon. Hisuian Goodra lacks pivoting unlike other RegenVest users such as Manaphy and Meloetta, so it finds its place on bulkier teams that can afford hard switching. Hisuian Goodra pairs well with strong but frail offensive threats such as Galarian Zapdos, wearing down the opponent's team and giving these threats the opportunity to clean up. Entry hazard removers such as Corviknight are great partners for Hisuian Goodra, allowing it to make full use of Regenerator. It also pairs well with hazard setters such as Deoxys-S thanks to Knock Off's ability to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes and Dragon Tail's phazing. Hisuian Goodra heavily relies on its item to function, so it dislikes being hit by Knock Off from Roaring Moon and Manaphy; it also struggles against physical attackers such as Iron Boulder and Galarian Zapdos, so physically defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Deoxys-D are great partners, as they can take hits for it, with the former also being able to absorb Knock Off.

Primordial Sea.description: Primordial Sea Volcanion excels as a fantastic wallbreaker with its great Special Attack and offensive typing. Rain-boosted Steam Eruption combined with Choice Specs allows Volcanion to 2HKO most Pokemon in tier, including most specially defensive walls such as RegenVest Garchomp, Meloetta, and Alolan Muk. Weather Ball dissuades promient Desolate Land users that might want to switch in to Volcanion such as Cinderace and Iron Moth. Earth Power is a more reliable way to deal with Desolate Land users like Iron Moth and Heatran, and it's a reliable way to hit Hisuian Goodra without missing. Focus Blast 2HKOes a would-be check in RegenVest Roaring Moon, as well as Hisuian Goodra after Spikes chip. Volcanion pairs well with entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Garchomp, which help wear down common RegenVest Pokemon like Goodra and Hisuian Goodra, and hazards also guarantee a 2HKO on Meloetta. Due to Volcanion's Stealth Rock weakness it pairs well with hazard removers like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also help pivot it in safely. Volcanion also pairs well with offensive pivots like Zapdos and Roaring Moon, which can help bring it in on targets like Corviknight.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Volcanion serves as a great mixed wallbreaker with a typing that also offers defensive utility. Flare Blitz is notably able to 2HKO RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, and Steam Eruption's burn chance deters would-be switch-ins like defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Earth Power reliably threatens Toxapex and Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Skeledirge, and Cinderace. Taunt can be used to hinder defensive walls with recovery such as Scream Tail and Quaquaval, while Will-O-Wisp is able to reliably burn switch-ins like defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Flame Charge is also a niche option to outspeed common revenge killers to Volcanion like Zapdos, Hisuian Arcanine, and Choice Band Galarian Zapdos. Magic Guard helps Volcanion with its weakness to entry hazards while also negating recoil from Flare Blitz and Life Orb. Offensive pivots such as Slither Wing and Iron Moth can bring Volcanion in against defensive cores featuring staples like Intimidate Corviknight and RegenVest users. Fast late-game cleaners like Chien-Pao and Regieleki also appreciate Volcanion's ability to weaken defensive checks like Quaquaval and common RegenVest users, which can allow them to take over games, while also providing speed control against faster threats to Volcanion like Zapdos, Hisuian Electrode, and Roaring Moon. Volcanion's susceptibility to being revenge killed by aformetioned threats makes defensive partners such as Corviknight and Meloetta essential, as they can tank hits and also help pivot to bring in Volcanion safely. Despite being immune to hazards, Volcanion still lacks recovery, so a teammate that can grant it longevity like Wish Scream Tail is also appreciated.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Primarina is an excellent wallbreaker thanks to its great typing and strong, nearly unresisted STAB combination. Weather Ball lets Primarina 2HKO RegenVest Swampert while still being able to hit Desolate Land users such as Heatran. Flip Turn allows Primarina to pivot away from problematic matchups like Empoleon and Blissey as well as predicted switch-ins in order to maintain momentum, while Psychic lets it hit Poison-types such as Toxapex and Desolate Land Iron Moth. Primarina is relatively slow and struggles to switch in, so it appreciates other slow pivots such as Corviknight and Swampert; in return, it can threaten wallbreakers that come in on them such as Cinderace and Roaring Moon. Corviknight especially is a great partner, as it can also remove entry hazards, which wear down Primarina very quickly due to its lack of recovery and frequent pivoting. Primarina struggles against special walls such as Manaphy, Meloetta, and Bulletproof Empoleon, so physical wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Iron Hands make for great teammates; in return, Primarina can apply pressure on physical walls such as Corviknight and Great Tusk for them, wearing down each other's checks.

RegenVest.description: With its great typing and natural bulk, Primarina can pivot into and check several of the tier's prominent threats including Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon. Psychic Noise threatens Iron Moth and denies recovery to it and Heatran, which could otherwise block Flip Turn with Desolate Land. Energy Ball hits Water-types like Swampert and opposing Primarina, while Surf provides a spammable Water-type move that also hits Steel-types like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Physical walls like Deoxys-D and Pecharunt appreciate Primarina's ability to switch into Dark-types that threaten them out like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao; in return, they can check threats like Iron Hands and Ogerpon-H that threaten Primarina. Frail offensive teammates like Deoxys-S, Azelf, and Chien-Pao appreciate Primarina's ability to switch into powerful attackers and safely pivot them in. Electric-types like Zapdos and Hisuian Electrode can easily break past Primarina, making Pokemon that can handle them like Roaring Moon and Volt Absorb Corviknight great teammates. Desolate Land users like Ceruledge, Heatran, and Iron Moth prevent Primarina from pivoting with Flip Turn and can threaten significant damage against it, making teammates that can deal with them like Primordial Sea Barraskewda and Zapdos appreciated. Primarina is also prone to getting worn down by entry hazards, so hazard removers like Corviknight and the aforementioned Great Tusk are good partners; it also forms a great defensive core with them, as it can help check Pokemon that pressure them like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon, giving them more opportunities to remove hazards.

Sheer Force.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack stat improved further by Sheer Force + Life Orb, solid coverage options, and access to Calm Mind, Primarina acts as a threatening wallbreaker and possible bulky sweeper. Energy Ball allows Primarina to nail Swampert and Manaphy. Psychic OHKOes Pecharunt and Desolate Land Iron Moth, while Calm Mind allows Primarina to OHKO Kingambit and RegenVest Iron Hands at +1. Teammates such as Gholdengo and Azelf appreciate Primarina's ability to handle both Swampert and Manaphy, as they tend to be troublesome for them. Primarina is also appreciated for being able to soft check Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao a couple times, which can relieve some pressure off of Great Tusk and Manaphy. Primarina's Water / Fairy typing allows it to hit almost all Pokemon neutrally while also being able to hit special walls like Roaring Moon, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads super effectively. Primarina tends to struggle against many Steel-type Pokemon, precisely Heatran, Empoleon, and Hisuian Goodra, so teammates that can deal with them like Great Tusk and Roaring Moon tend to be good partners. Primarina also struggles to safely switch in on many physical attackers, so slow, physically defensive pivots like Corviknight and Mandibuzz are good teammates. Entry hazard chip quickly wears down Primarina, so hazard removal options such as Great Tusk and the aforementioned Corviknight and Mandibuzz are quite valuable.

Physical Wall.description: Toxapex leverages its high defensive stats and plethora of useful utility moves to act as a stout defensive wall and disruptor. Prankster + Haze lets Toxapex shut down threatening setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Volcarona, and Stored Power Iron Crown. Corrosion + Toxic gives Toxapex the ability to punish Steel-types such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Desolate Land Heatran, which can otherwise shrug off Toxapex's attacks, while Toxic Spikes can pressure more offensively oriented teams. Chilling Water deters physical attackers such as Zamazenta and Great Tusk from switching into Toxapex, while Infestation can rack up chip damage on foes such as Corviknight and Empoleon. Black Sludge give Toxapex greater longevity, while Rocky Helmet punishes physical attackers such as Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, as well as general U-turn spam. Eject Button is a niche option that lets Toxapex pivot in teammates safely and check Poltergeist Ceruledge after activation. Toxapex fits best on stall teams due to its passivity and ability to check setup sweepers that could potentially run rampant. Certain wallbreakers such as Iron Boulder, Garchomp, and Iron Hands are able to power through Toxapex, so teammates that can check these such as Great Tusk and Corviknight are greatly appreciated; Toxapex can in return take on Chien-Pao and Fire-types such as Cinderace and Ogerpon-H. Toxapex is horrified by Electric- and Psychic-types such as Zapdos, Deoxys-S, and Azelf, so teammates that can reliably take these on such as Hisuian Goodra, Mandibuzz, and Meloetta are helpful.

Galvanize.description: Kommo-o finds a decent niche on offensive teams as a mixed attacker with strong coverage. Boomburst scares off walls such as Mandibuzz, Corviknight, and Manaphy. Clanging Scales threatens Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Pecharunt, while Close Combat notably allows Kommo-o to smack special walls like Blissey, Swampert, and Volt Absorb Empoleon attempting to check it. Stealth Rock synergizes well with Kommo-o's ability to scare away entry hazard removers like the aforementioned Mandibuzz and Corviknight. Clangorous Soul allows it to act as a passable setup sweeper instead, preventing threats like Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder from revenge killing it while increasing its offensive capabilities. Life Orb is typically preferred for its consistent damage boost, but Throat Spray can be used on Clangorous Soul sets to avoid recoil. Kommo-o's lack of longevity necessitates either teammates that can make up for its absent defensive utility like Corviknight and Manaphy or offensive teammates that can keep up the pressure like Iron Moth and Chien-Pao. Select revenge killers like Dragonite, Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, and Azelf naturally outspeed Kommo-o even after a Clangorous Soul, so answers to them like Kingambit, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon make for good partners. Kommo-o appreciates pivots like Azelf, Sandy Shocks, and Roaring Moon because they can pivot out on their checks like Blissey, Empoleon, and Corviknight and safely bring it in to start threatening the opposing team. Kommo-o greatly appreciates dual screens support from setters like Corviknight and Deoxys-S allowing it to have an easier time setting up with Clangorous Soul or supporting its teammates with Stealth Rock; alternatively, Sticky Web from Smeargle and Ribombee can help it outspeed Choice Scarf revenge killers like Latios, Azelf, and Roaring Moon after a Clangorous Soul.

Court Change.description: With Cinderace's high Speed, high-Base Power STAB move in Pyro Ball, and general utility, it makes for a decent offensive pivot. U-turn lets Cinderace pivot on checks like Manaphy, Primarina, Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, and Skarmory while also safely getting teammates in that can take these checks on such as Sandy Shocks, Iron Hands, and Galarian Zapdos. Court Change lets Cinderace support its teammates by potentially clearing its side of entry hazards and using them against the opponent while also being able to steal dual screens. Will-O-Wisp lets Cinderace cripple potential switch-ins such as Dragonite, Garchomp, and Great Tusk, but it can instead use Taunt to cripple defensive Pokemon like Deoxys-D, Scream Tail, and Pecharunt. With High Jump Kick Cinderace can cover Primordial Sea switch-ins such as Barraskewda and Ogerpon-W. Frail offensive Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Barraskewda, and Azelf appreciate the presence of Cinderace due to it not only allowing them easier entry onto the field but also removing checks to them such as Corviknight, Scream Tail, and Mandibuzz. Cinderace falters when having to deal with either Primordial Sea users like Zapdos and Primarina or Well-Baked Body users such as Gholdengo and Corviknight, so having teammates such as Swampert, Empoleon, and RegenVest Roaring Moon to check these Pokemon is immensely helpful. As a final note, Cinderace tends to be used on more offensive teams, but with Court Change not fully removing hazards, it's not recommended that you use multiple hazard-weak teammates with it.

Magic Guard.description: Cinderace's high Speed, high Attack, and wide utility movepool make it a versatile attacker that can both dish out substantial damage and disrupt opposing Pokemon indirectly. High Jump Kick hits Garganacl while also being the best option against Well-Baked Body users such as Corviknight and Skarmory, and Gunk Shot hits Scream Tail, Primarina, and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Cinderace can use Will-O-Wisp to cripple would-be switch-ins such as Great Tusk, Garchomp, Swampert, and Dragonite, pivot out on them with U-turn, or carry Gunk Shot for maximum coverage. Swords Dance helps Cinderace wallbreak, while Taunt prevents foes from inflicting status, recovering, or controlling entry hazards, which Cinderace can control itself with Court Change. In particular, Taunt improves Cinderace's matchup against Unaware users such as Mandibuzz and Scream Tail by prohibiting their recovery. Life Orb amplifies Cinderace's damage output, while Focus Sash provides recourse against Pokemon that would otherwise OHKO it, allowing it to score surprise KOs or get off valuable utility moves in a pinch. Magic Guard removes Life Orb recoil, the chance for Focus Sash to be broken by indirect damage, and Cinderace's vulnerability to Entry Hazard damage. Cinderace's ability to pressure Corviknight and Skarmory is appreciated by other wallbreakers that can struggle to deal with them like Roaring Moon, Iron Boulder, and Barraskewda, all of which Cinderace can help enter the field with U-turn. Cinderace is threatened by faster Pokemon like Zamazenta and Deoxys-S, so defensive Pokemon that can switch into these such as Empoleon, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz are helpful partners. Well-Baked Body Gholdengo completely walls Cinderace, making partners that can force out or eliminate it like Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Gengar valuable teammates.

Choice Band.description: Cinderace leverages its high Attack and Speed stats alongside its high-Base Power moves to be a great offensive pivot and wallbreaker, threatening common physical walls like Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Deoxys-D. High Jump Kick is Cinderace's best move against Well-Baked Body Steel-types, doing sizable damage to Corviknight and Skarmory and OHKOing Kingambit. U-turn lets Cinderace pivot out of problematic matchups like Ceruledge and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo while also threatening Latios, whereas Gunk Shot threatens Primarina and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Desolate Land gives Cinderace a very high chance of OHKOing offensive Great Tusk after Spikes damage and lets it come in and threaten out Primordial Sea users like Zapdos and, when they're locked into Water-type moves, Barraskewda and Ogerpon-W. Alternatively, Sword of Ruin lets High Jump Kick OHKO Ogerpon-W and 2HKO Well-Baked Body Corviknight after slight chip damage. Fast physical attackers like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao appreciate Cinderace threatening their checks like non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight and RegenVest Primarina, letting them sweep once these foes have been removed. In return, they can pressure Well-Baked Body Steel-types that trouble Cinderace like Gholdengo and Corviknight. While fast, Cinderace is also frail and prone to getting revenge killed by faster foes like Iron Boulder and Choice Scarf Azelf, so teammates that can deal with them like Fluffy Corviknight and Empoleon are appreciated. Additionally, Cinderace is prone to getting worn down by entry hazards, making hazard removers like Great Tusk and the aforementioned Corviknight great partners.

Swords Dance.description: Cinderace's high Attack and Speed combined with great coverage options and Swords Dance turn it into a powerful wallbreaker and cleaner. High Jump Kick threatens Roaring Moon and OHKOes Well-Baked Body Kingambit, while Gunk Shot threatens to cripple switch-ins such as Manaphy, Zapdos, Kommo-o, and physically defensive Garchomp. Life Orb lets High Jump Kick OHKO RegenVest Roaring Moon and lets Gunk Shot 2HKO Primordial Sea Zapdos, while Heavy-Duty Boots increases Cinderace's longevity. Desolate Land lets Cinderace come in on and force out Primordial Sea users like Zapdos if safely pivoted in by a teammate while also letting +2 Life Orb-boosted Pyro Ball OHKO defensive Great Tusk. Sword of Ruin + Heavy-Duty Boots provides more damage on Cinderace's coverage moves at the cost of a worse matchup into Primordial Sea and lowered damage on Pyro Ball. Fast cleaners such as Barraskewda and Dragonite appreciate Cinderace's ability to pressure their walls like Corviknight and Scream Tail, opening up the way for them to sweep late-game. Special pivots like Azelf, Zapdos, and Latios are appreciated, as they can pivot Cinderace in against their switch-ins, such as Empoleon and Hisuian Goodra. Cinderace's frailty means it's easily revenge killed by most Pokemon faster than it like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Azelf, so teammates that can take a hit for it and pivot it in such as Corviknight and Manaphy are appreciated. Cinderace is also completely walled by Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, so teammates that can threaten it like Garchomp and Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Utility.description: Cinderace is a good utility pivot thanks to its high Speed and great supporting movepool. U-turn lets it pivot out against Well-Baked Body Pokemon like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit, as well as Primordial Sea users like Zapdos, Ogerpon-W, and Manaphy. Court Change punishes opposing teams for setting entry hazards or dual screens. Super Fang can be used instead to chip switch-ins like Kommo-o, Garganacl, and Quaquaval that Cinderace cannot meaningfully damage otherwise. Taunt prevents status moves, entry hazards, and recovery, which can help against foes like Scream Tail, while Will-O-Wisp cripples checks like Garchomp, Kommo-o, and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Cinderace is threatened by Primordial Sea users like Barraskewda, Ogerpon-W, and Primarina, which force it out, making walls like defensive Zapdos, Kommo-o, and Empoleon pair well with it. Offensive pivots such as Galarian Zapdos, Meowscarada, and Sandy Shocks pair well with Cinderace, as they form a VoltTurn core with it, being able to pivot it in to threaten walls like Corviknight, Meloetta, Hisuian Goodra. In return, Cinderace can pivot these teammates in to threaten its switch-ins like Kommo-o, Garaganacl, and Quaquaval.

Primordial Sea.description: Inteleon is a decent cleaner and wallbreaker thanks to its high Special Attack and Speed, threatening many offensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Scream Tail, and Gholdengo. U-turn lets it pivot out of unfavorable matchups like RegenVest Manaphy and Primarina and forms a VoltTurn core with other pivots like Roaring Moon and Meowscarada. Mud Shot threatens Fire-types like Iron Moth and Ceruledge that could otherwise utilize Desolate Land to comfortably switch into a Weather Ball and OHKOes Heatran. Ice Beam snipes Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Dragonite. Physical teammates like Zamazenta and Roaring Moon appreciate Inteleon's ability to threaten their switch-ins like Pecharunt and Great Tusk, respectively, letting them rip massive holes in the opponent's team once these foes are removed; in return, they can threaten walls like Empoleon and Manaphy, which Inteleon struggles against. Entry hazard support from the likes of Scream Tail and Ting-Lu helps Inteleon against special walls like Empoleon and RegenVest users like Manaphy and Primarina,(AC) which it otherwise struggles to break through. Inteleon is also vulnerable to being worn down by hazards, so teammates that can remove them like Corviknight and Great Tusk are good partners. Furthermore, Inteleon's frailty leaves it severely threatened by faster revenge killers like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, making teammates that can deal with them like the aforementioned Corviknight and Great Tusk greatly appreciated.

Physically Defensive.description: Corviknight's unparalleled role compression as a physical wall, entry hazard remover, and slow pivot that doesn't need Regenerator makes it a defensive staple on the majority of teams. Fluffy provides the most protection against wallbreakers like Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, Iron Boulder, and Roaring Moon while not letting Corviknight fall victim to Scrappy Great Tusk, whereas Intimidate provides additional protection against Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-C at the cost of needing a secondary physical check to deal with the aforementioned threats reliably. Brave Bird is Corviknight's strongest neutral move and hits Ghost-types and key targets like Great Tusk and Galarian Zapdos, while Body Press fits well on Intimidate sets to do more damage to Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-C, and Chien-Pao. Corviknight is exceedingly passive, so it needs powerful and fast offensive teammates like Barraskewda and Azelf to re-gain momentum; in exchange, it provides them safe entry with its slow U-turn and entry hazard removal. Slower wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Ceruledge also appreciate Corviknight's slow pivoting services. Corviknight, especially Fluffy variants, needs a teammate like Swampert, Manaphy, or Well-Baked Body Gholdengo to handle the Fire-types it cannot check. Hazard-weak teammates like Chien-Pao and the Ogerpon formes appreciate Corviknight's ability to remove hazards semi-reliably.

Dual Screens.description: Prankster and an excellent defensive typing enable Corviknight to set dual screens multiple times a battle for hyper offense teams. Taunt lets Corviknight prevent opposing Corviknight from removing dual screens with Defog, stop Pokemon like Deoxys-D and Great Tusk from setting entry hazards, and prevent Pokemon like Dragonite and Gholdengo from setting up. U-turn is used to pivot out once dual screens have been set up. Prankster Corviknight should be used with setup sweepers that appreciate dual screens support such as Dragonite, Volcarona, and Iron Boulder. Fire-types like Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Heatran and Electric-types like Zapdos can deal heavy damage to Corviknight, so having Dragon-types that can check them like Roaring Moon and Dragonite is appreciated.

Immunity Ability.description: Corviknight's incredible Steel / Flying typing combined with its access to U-turn makes it a great defensive pivot, aided further by its abilities of Well-Baked Body or Volt Absorb. With Well-Baked Body, Corviknight can reliably check Fire-types such as Cinderace, Heatran, and Ogerpon-H, while Volt Absorb allows it to check many Electric-type Pokemon such as Zapdos, Sandy Shocks, and Hisuian Electrode. With Defog, Corviknight can help control entry hazards, and with the help of its abilities, it can clear them in front of hazard setters such as Desolate Land Landorus and Heatran with Well-Baked Body or Sandy Shocks and Archaludon with Volt Absorb. Corviknight will most often run Leftovers for extra healing, though it can also run Eject Button with Well-Baked Body to safely bring in a teammate once and be a better check to Ceruledge. With an EV spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD, Corviknight can better check Pokemon like Roaring Moon as well as Cinderace with Well-Baked Body, while with an alternate EV spread of 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD, it can reliably check Pokemon like Latios as well as Zapdos with Volt Absorb; it should also be noted that Well-Baked Body sets prefer to be physically defensive, while Volt Absorb sets prefer to be specially defensive. Corviknight tends to be a great assistant to wallbreakers such as Ceruledge, Barraskewda, and Chien-Pao that appreciate entry hazards being removed as well as being pivoted onto the field safely. Corviknight can struggle against Pokemon that hit it hard regardless of its abilities such as Choice Band Roaring Moon, Zamazenta, and Chien-Pao, so having teammates such as Great Tusk, Scream Tail, and Primarina can help. Corviknight also struggles against special attackers like Gengar, Primarina, and Gholdengo, even if it is specially defensive, so partners like Blissey and Bulletproof Empoleon can check these foes.

Choice Band.description: With great offensive stats and a spammable move in Flip Turn, Barraskewda serves as an excellent offensive pivot that's capable of outpacing the majority of the metagame. Close Combat lets it deal with foes that resist its Water-type moves such as Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-W, and Empoleon, while Aqua Jet lets it pick off weakened foes that normally outspeed it such as Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Hisuian Electrode, as well as foes that have set up, such as Volcarona and Great Tusk. Drill Run and Psychic Fangs also threaten Water-resistant foes, with Drill Run OHKOing Desolate Land Fire-types such as Iron Moth, Heatran, and Ceruledge and Psychic Fangs threatening Quaquaval and Kommo-o. Barraskewda takes great advantage of weakened walls such as Corviknight and Deoxys-D, making physical wallbreakers such as Iron Boulder, Galarian Zapdos, and Ceruledge good partners. Specially offensive pivots such as Hisuian Electrode and Azelf form great VoltTurn cores with Barraskewda, since they're able to threaten each other's checks, with Barraskewda forcing out special walls such as Meloetta and Swampert while they threaten physical walls such as Corviknight and Quaquaval in return. Barraskewda is very frail and easily OHKOed by faster foes such as Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Azelf, which makes defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Swampert necessary. It also struggles a lot with entry hazards, making hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Corviknight appreciated.

Shell Smash.description: With its unique access to Shell Smash and Stored Power, Polteageist carves itself a niche as a decent sweeper, aided by Queenly Majesty against priority moves from the likes of Slither Wing and Dragonite. Stored Power, after a Shell Smash boost, lets Polteageist blast through anything that isn't a Dark-type or a dedicated special wall. Giga Drain allows Polteageist to OHKO Swampert after slight chip damage as well as letting it deal great damage to both Ting-Lu and Chien-Pao. Polteageist can pair well with Pokemon like Dragonite, Zamazenta, and Iron Hands, which can bait in Pokemon that it can scare out such as Pecharunt and Deoxys-D. Polteageist struggles with getting onto the field to set up due to entry hazards invalidating its Focus Sash and it being frail, so it usually appreciates Taunt leads like Corviknight and Deoxys-S and entry hazard removers like Great Tusk. Polteageist also cannot hurt most Dark-types in a meaningful way, so it enjoys having teammates like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Iron Hands, which can help remove most of them. Even though Polteageist can outspeed most unboosted Pokemon after a Shell Smash boost, it still struggles with Deoxys-S and most Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Azelf, Roaring Moon, and Latios because they can easily outspeed it and KO it, so having speed control support from either Sticky Web or priority users like Dragonite is appreciated. Finally, Polteageist only works on offensive teams, as it's unable to provide much outside of setting up once and attempting to sweep, so supporting that sweep with teammates that provide either entry hazards, like Deoxys-S and Smeargle, or dual screens, like Corviknight and Regieleki, is a great boon to Polteageist.

Choice Band.description: With Zamazenta's high Attack only compounded by Sword of Ruin and excellent Speed tier that allows it to outspeed nearly the entire unboosted metagame, it serves as a potent wallbreaker that is capable of 2HKOing even dedicated physical walls like Mandibuzz and defensive Great Tusk with Close Combat. Crunch 2HKOes Psychic- and Ghost-types like Deoxys-D, Pecharunt, and physically defensive Gholdengo variants that would switch into Close Combat. Stone Edge helps against Flying-types like Zapdos and Dragonite that might otherwise survive a hit and KO Zamazenta back. Heavy Slam covers Fairy-type switch-ins like Scream Tail and Primarina. Due to Zamazenta's lack of reliable recovery, it appreciates entry hazard removal support from Great Tusk and Corviknight, the latter of which can also serve as a slow pivot to bring it in safely and help preserve its HP so it can take advantage of its great natural bulk. Zamazenta benefits from Knock Off users like Roaring Moon and Iron Treads removing Rocky Helmets, keeping it from getting worn down. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Deoxys-D help to chip down the likes of Fluffy Corviknight and Great Tusk to make them easier for Zamazenta to KO. Zamazenta is susceptible to being revenge killed by Choice Scarf Azelf, Dragonite, and most Deoxys-S variants, so defensive walls like Deoxys-D, Hisuian Goodra, and Scream Tail that can switch into them are needed.

IronPress.description: IronPress Zamazenta provides a threatening combination of defensive utility and offensive presence in the same teamslot, checking threats like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and all Ogerpon formes. Iron Defense lets it bolster its already impressive Defense while boosting Body Press's damage output, allowing it set up on walls like Corviknight and Great Tusk. Substitute allows it to avoid status like Toxic from non-Prankster Pecharunt and Toxapex and Thunder Wave from Gholdengo. Stone Edge 2HKOes Dragonite and Zapdos, while Heavy Slam 2HKOes Scream Tail. Zamazenta's vulnerability to entry hazards makes good hazard removal options like Great Tusk and Corviknight valuable. Special wallbreakers like Deoxys-S, Primarina, and Choice Scarf Azelf threaten Zamazenta, so teammates that can switch into these wallbreakers like Empoleon, Magic Guard or RegenVest Roaring Moon, and Heatran are helpful. Zamazenta's inability to break through Primarina makes teammates that can muscle through them like Sandy Shocks, Hisuian Electrode, and Deoxys-S good partners.

Zamazenta-C leverages its Fighting / Steel typing and high Defense and Speed to be a decent Body Press sweeper that's able to switch in and set up on common Pokemon like Corviknight, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon. Stone Edge helps against Zapdos, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge, while Substitute helps it set up against would-be switch-ins like Iron Hands and Great Tusk as well as shielding it from status afflictions from moves like Manaphy's Scald and Corrosion Pecharun't Toxic. Zamazenta-C plays best on offensive teams, so it appreciates entry hazards from Pokemon like Skarmory and Deoxys-D and dual screens support from Pokemon like Corviknight and Deoxys-S, which help it take KOs and set up, respectively. Zamazenta-C also appreciates Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Gengar that are able to take down Deoxys-D, Gholdengo, and Pecharunt, as otherwise it is unable to make progress at all.

Dual Screens.description: With the highest base Speed in the game, Regieleki can enable high-powered setup sweepers like Manaphy, Dragonite, and Iron Hands on hyper offense teams as a dual screens lead, though it's more niche than other dual screens setters. With Refrigerate, Rapid Spin is a guaranteed way to remove entry hazards even in the face of Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Pecharunt. However, Regieleki isn't the best to rely on for Rapid Spin all of the time, so teammates like Great Tusk and Quaquaval can help as additional spinners. Explosion lets Regieleki get its teammates in safely, do massive damage to foes like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon, and prevent dual screens removal via Defog. Many setup sweepers, most notably Gholdengo, Ceruledge, and Iron Hands, appreciate Regieleki's dual screens support while also fending off priority from Pokemon like Slither Wing and Prankster Corviknight, which would otherwise prevent it from setting dual screens. Regieleki similarly doesn't enjoy Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Meowscarada, as they are the only relevant Pokemon able to outspeed it instantly, so having checks to them such as Kingambit, Iron Hands, and Zamazenta can help. As a final note, Regieleki is exclusively a hyper offense lead meant to support Pokemon such as Iron Boulder, Volcarona, and Kingambit by providing them with extra opportunities to set up and win the game.

Calm Mind.description: Ursaluna-B uses its great Special Attack and physical bulk to be a decent Calm Mind sweeper. Calm Mind lets it boost past and break through foes like Corviknight and RegenVest Manaphy and Swampert, while Moonlight provides additional longevity, letting it use the aforementioned walls as setup fodder. Storm Drain turns RegenVest users like Swampert, Manaphy, and Primarina into setup fodder and lets it check Barraskewda; alternatively, Well-Baked Body lets Ursaluna-B counter Fire-types like Ceruledge lacking Close Combat, Iron Moth, and Heatran, letting it safely set up on them, while Fluffy lets it deal with physical attackers, using Dragonite as setup fodder and checking Fighting-types like Iron Hands and Great Tusk. 252 Special Attack EVs and a Modest nature lets Ursaluna-B OHKO Dragonite at +1 and defensive Great Tusk, while 252 Defense EVs and a Bold nature help Ursaluna-B better check physical attackers like Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder. 15 Speed IVs let Ursaluna-B underspeed Corviknight, preventing it from safely using Roost or U-turn to slow pivot to a teammate that can handle Ursaluna-B. Powerful special attackers like Azelf and Latios appreciate Ursaluna-B's ability to handle threats like Roaring Moon and pressure checks like Swampert for them; in return, they can threaten Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Great Tusk that could threaten it. Ursaluna-B's low Speed leaves it susceptible to threats that can OHKO it like Chien-Pao and Latios, so teammates that can deal with them like RegenVest Primarina are appreciated. Ursaluna-B's low Special Defense also lets powerful attackers like Latios and Deoxys-S OHKO it prior to setting up, so specially defensive teammates that can check them like Empoleon and Heatran are good pairings. Earth Eater users like Gholdengo and Empoleon can wall Ursaluna-B, so teammates that can threaten them like Roaring Moon and Scrappy Great Tusk are appreciated.

Sheer Force.description: Enamorus-T's excellent Special Attack, solid bulk, and plentiful coverage options make it a decent wallbreaker able to threaten common special walls like Swampert and Empoleon. Earth Power threatens Fire-types such as Heatran, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge as well as non-Ground-immune Empoleon and Gholdengo, while Mystical Fire threatens non-Well-Baked Body Steel-types like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit. Superpower nails special walls like Blissey, Ground-immune Empoleon, and Hisuian Goodra, while Grass Knot specifically targets Swampert, guaranteeing a KO on it after a Moonblast. A Rash nature is used when running Superpower; otherwise, Modest is optimal. Special sweepers and cleaners like Scream Tail and Azelf appreciate Enamorus-T being able to threaten their walls like Swampert and Empoleon, letting them clean late-game. Entry hazard support from the likes of Ting-Lu and Garchomp is greatly appreciated, as it helps Enamorus-T break through walls like RegenVest Manaphy and Meloetta that it can otherwise struggle to break through. Enamorus-T's awful Speed leaves it outsped and OHKOed by many offensive threats like Iron Boulder, Gholdengo, and Chien-Pao, making teammates that can deal with them and pivot it in like Corviknight, RegenVest Swampert, and Primarina, respectively, good partners.

Choice Item.description: Thanks to its high base Attack and Speed stats and U-turn, Meowscarada functions incredibly as an offensive pivot and wallbreaker. U-turn allows Meowscarada to switch out of problematic matchups such as Corviknight and Kingambit and into threats like Iron Moth and Iron Hands to scare them away. Trick enables Meowscarada to punish bulky walls like Corviknight, Skarmory, and Mandibuzz looking to switch in on it; alternatively, Triple Axel provides a way for Meowscarada to hit Dragonite, Mandibuzz, and Chesnaught for super effective damage. Meowscarada can use Choice Band to OHKO Deoxys-D, Scream Tail, and Garganacl after Stealth Rock, while Choice Scarf gives it the ability to outspeed incredibly fast foes such as Deoxys-S, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Roaring Moon. Since Meowscarada struggles against Corviknight, Skarmory, and Kingambit, it appreciates partners like Zapdos, Sandy Shocks, and Archaludon that can pressure them; in return, Meowscarada can threaten Swampert and Meloetta, which these teammates struggle against. While Meowscarada's Attack stat is adequate, it still appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Deoxys-D, Garchomp, and Heatran, as Stealth Rock or one layer of Spikes allows Meowscarada to have a very high chance of OHKOing Deoxys-D and Scream Tail.

Physically Defensive.description: Due to its incredible utility moves in Rapid Spin and Knock Off, longevity from Roost, and good typing, Quaquaval functions incredibly as an entry hazard remover and pivot and checks Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Barraskewda. Quaquaval has a multitude of viable abilities, such as Scrappy to let Rapid Spin and Low Kick affect Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Ceruledge as well as Intimidate and Fluffy to further increase its bulk, allowing it to more safely switch in on top physical threats such as Roaring Moon and offensive Great Tusk. Thanks to U-turn, Quaquaval can allow frail attackers including Azelf and Meowscarada to safely switch in. Knock Off can be used for its general reliability and utility, while Low Kick wears down opposing Hisuian Goodra and Blissey. Quaquaval is quite vulnerable to special attackers such as Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Hisuian Electrode. To counter these significant threats, RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta can be used to safely switch in on most of their attacks and threaten to deal decent chip damage to them with Knock Off or U-turn. Some teammates that benefit from Quaquaval's presence include Roaring Moon and Deoxys-S, as they don't enjoy taking Spikes damage, so they appreciate its hazard removing capabilities.

Magic Guard.description: Quaquaval is a decent wallbreaker, using its strong STAB moves, and solid Attack stat to burst through bulky opponents foes like Great Tusk, Deoxys-D, and Skarmory. Brave Bird hits Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Ceruledge on the switch-in, but Quaquaval can use Close Combat to help against Pokemon like Heatran and Manaphy, though this does have the drawback of making it easier to be revenge killed. Rapid Spin is used as not only entry hazard removal for Quaquaval and its teammates but also a way to let it outspeed and threaten foes like Hisuian Electrode, Galarian Zapdos, and Iron Boulder. Knock Off can be used to both remove items from Pokemon like Corviknight, Deoxys-D, and Mandibuzz, as well as hit Ghost-types such as Ceruledge and Gholdengo. U-turn is a less prominent option to be able to pivot on checks like Corviknight and Manaphy. Roost is used to keep Quaquaval healthy potentially allowing it to outlast its checks, while Swords Dance can be used as a way to let it end games by blasting through its checks like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and physically defensive Manaphy. Offensive Psychic-types such as Azelf, Iron Boulder, and Deoxys-S appreciate Quaquaval's presence, as it's able to take on Dark- and Steel-types such as Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Gholdengo for them. Quaquaval is slow, and struggles to deal with faster foes such as Deoxys-S, Dragonite, and Latios, so it benefits from having teammates like Swampert, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz to help with checking them defensively and bringing it in safely.

The Salt Cure.description: Garganacl is a tough defensive wall that uses Salt Cure to wear down defensive Pokemon, like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Corviknight, and utilizes its ability selection to check a variety of different Pokemon. Fluffy allows Garganacl to check Kingambit and Iron Boulder, Water Absorb lets it reliably switch in on defensive Manaphy as well as help with checking Choice-locked Water-types like Barraskewda and Primarina, and Earth Eater lets it check Roaring Moon and Dragonite running Earthquake. Stealth Rock lets Garganacl support its teammates by providing entry hazards, while with Iron Defense or Curse, Garganacl can set up on and more easily check Pokemon like Iron Hands, Ceruledge, and Dragonite, and boost Body Press or Earthquake, depending on the set. When using Body Press, Garganacl can more efficiently take on Chien-Pao as well as a majority of other Pokemon, while with Earthquake, it can deal with Iron Boulder and Pecharunt. Protect lets Garganacl deal extra damage with Salt Cure active as well as gain some extra Leftovers recovery. Garganacl can either use Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots, the former letting it gain more recovery through Protect and the latter helping Garganacl switch in more often. Garganacl provides great defensive support to frail offensive Pokemon, like Iron Moth, Gengar, and Galarian Zapdos, as a to check faster Pokemon like Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Iron Boulder. Garganacl can struggle against special attackers, such as Deoxys-S, Azelf, and offensive Gholdengo, so having specially defensive teammates, like Hisuian Goodra, Manaphy, and Blissey, can help. Garganacl enjoys being on more defensive teams for having teammates that can take on physical attackers with it, such as Pecharunt, Mandibuzz, and Primarina, as it struggles to reliably check Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Zamazenta, and Barraskewda.

Choice Band.description: Ceruledge has the perfect combination of traits to become a terrifying wallbreaker, boasting two of the best offensive STAB typings, high-Base Power attacks, and a naturally good matchup against the tier's most common physical wall, Corviknight. Bitter Blade's healing is greatly appreciated to offset Stealth Rock chip damage, and Close Combat flips the table on potential answers such as Roaring Moon and Well-Baked Body Kingambit. Shadow Sneak makes Ceruledge a potent revenge killer and cleaner, picking off weakened setup sweepers like Volcarona and Ogerpon-C, and threatening to OHKO Iron Boulder, Gengar, and non-Psychic Surge Deoxys-S. An Adamant nature helps Ceruledge secure certain KOs, most notably OHKOing Swampert with Poltergeist, but Jolly allows it to outspeed Gholdengo and neutral-natured Great Tusk. Ceruledge requires slow pivots like Primarina, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz to get it onto the field, with the former covering Latios and the latter two providing valuable Defog support while also checking dangerous revenge killers like Roaring Moon and Dragonite. Ceruledge also pairs well with offensive pivots like Azelf and Zapdos, both of which require help to break past RegenVest users such as Manaphy and Swampert; in return, they give it more opportunities to come in to wallbreak. However, Ceruledge cannot be paired with Knock Off as this nullifies Poltergeist, limiting its synergy with the aforementioned RegenVests users and common Choice Scarf users like Roaring Moon and Meowscarada. Ceruledge is quite slow relative to other offensive wallbreakers, so it needs speed control in the form of Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, the latter of which also baits in and pivots on Corviknight and Skarmory.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Ceruledge is one of the tier's most potent wallbreakers and setup sweepers thanks to its high base Attack, great STAB coverage, and Swords Dance. Shadow Sneak picks off weakened foes like Gholdengo and Iron Boulder and OHKOes frailer targets like Sheer Force Deoxys-S, while Close Combat nails potential Dark-type switch-ins like Roaring Moon. Sword of Ruin offers the most all-around damage amplification, while Desolate Land supercharges Bitter Blade and provides a useful immunity to Water; similarly, Life Orb provides extra power, letting Ceruledge achieve feats like OHKOing Deoxys-D, while Heavy-Duty Boots is useful on teams with weak entry hazard removal. Ceruledge can be overwhelmed by Pokemon like Barraskewda, Ogerpon-W, and Psychic Surge Deoxys-S, making defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Deoxys-D good teammates. Ceruledge's low Speed means that it can easily be outsped by foes, making offensive Pokemon like Choice Scarf Azelf, Dragonite, and Chien-Pao good teammates that help make up for it thanks to their high Speed. Ceruledge's poor defenses and weakness to entry hazards makes slow, hazard-removing pivots like Corviknight and Mandibuzz ideal teammates. Because Ceruledge relies heavily on Poltergeist, it has poor synergy teammates that frequently use Knock Off such as Manaphy and Swampert.

Bulk Up.description: Palafin is an extremely niche setup sweeper that has one of the strongest priority moves in the tier and not much else, as it is forced to use Zero to Hero to transform. Substitute prevents it from being statused from Pecharunt, Gholdengo, and Manaphy while allowing it to set up on passive targets like Corviknight, Swampert, and the aforementioned Manaphy. Bulk Up makes up for its lack of power, since it lacks an ability and item that increases its damage output. Drain Punch keeps Palafin healthy against checks like Corviknight and Manaphy and allows it to damage Water-immune foes like Iron Moth and Heatran. Ice Punch smacks Dragon-types like Dragonite and Roaring Moon, while Zen Headbutt OHKOes Iron Moth. Palafin fits on bulkier or balance teams as a late-game sweeper, so partners that can wear the opposing team down over time like Magic Guard Roaring Moon, Hisuian Electrode, and Deoxys-S are appreciated; entry hazard setters like Scream Tail, Heatran, and Great Tusk are also beneficial with their ability to chip down foes over time. Palafin is checked offensively by threats like Dragonite, Desolate Land Ceruledge, and Scream Tail, so teammates like Corviknight, Well-Baked Body Mandibuzz, and Heatran handle these threats. Physical walls like Pecharunt and Skarmory can wall Palafin consistently, so partners that can force them out like Deoxys-S and Sandy Shocks pair well with it. Desolate Land users like Iron Moth Roaring Moon, Primordial Sea Zapdos, and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo can deal with Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Heatran, making for great partners.

Swords Dance.description: Kingambit acts as valuable sweeper and cleaner on offensive teams, providing a refreshing blend of offensive and defensive utility in the form of strong priority in Sucker Punch and the option of having a valuable type immunity. Swords Dance boosts Kingambit's Attack to nuclear levels, OHKOing physically defensive Manaphy and threatening to 2HKO Fluffy Corviknight with Kowtwo Cleave after light chip. Adaptability provides even more power; with Black Glasses, it can let Kingambit achieve feats like OHKOing threats such as Dragonite after a Swords Dance. Well-Baked Body allows Kingambit to check and set up on Ogerpon-H, Heatran, and Iron Moth and provides an immunity to burn, while Earth Eater turns Dragonite, Roaring Moon, and double dance Garchomp into setup fodder. The given EV spread allows Kingambit to outspeed RegenVest Manaphy and Jirachi. Kingambit requires teammates that can threaten Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Zamazenta, as these Pokemon can freely switch into it. As a result, Pokemon like Latios, Zapdos, and Pixilate Scream Tail make for good teammates with their ability to comfortably force them out. Offensive pivots that can break holes in the opposing team like the aforementioned Latios and Zapdos, Roaring Moon, and Barraskewda are strongly recommended to enable Kingambit to clean late-game. Entry hazard setters like Great Tusk, Empoleon, and the aforementioned Scream Tail pair well with Kingambit by helping to passively wittle down its checks like Corviknight, physically defensive Manaphy, and Zamazenta.

Physically Defensive.description: Great Tusk's gargantuan physical bulk and access to valuable utility moves make it a valuable defensive presence in the metagame, especially since it is the best user of Rapid Spin and one of the few viable forms of entry hazard control. Body Press, when coupled with maximum Defense investment, deals consistent damage to Corviknight, while Ice Spinner can be used to hit Flying-type switch-ins like both Zapdos formes and Dragonite. Knock Off debilitates switch-ins like Corviknight and Zapdos by removing their Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots, respectively. Alternatively, Great Tusk can use Stealth Rock if none of its teammates are capable of setting it. Bulk Up can also be considered to increase Great Tusk's offensive presence, but is typically less preferred than other utility options. Scrappy notably prevents Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Pecharunt from spinblocking Great Tusk. Alternatively, Regenerator provides Great Tusk with reliable recovery it otherwise lacks, while Fluffy allows it to better check attackers such as Roaring Moon and allows a teammate like Swampert to use Regenerator instead. Heavy-Duty Boots ensures Great Tusk can more reliably remove entry hazards by avoiding chip damage from them, while Leftovers provides recovery for non-Regenerator sets, and Rocky Helmet can be used to punish attackers that make contact. Offensive Pokemon that appreciate entry hazards off the field such as Azelf and Chien-Pao pair well with Great Tusk's Rapid Spin support. Due to its poor special bulk, Great Tusk appreciates specially bulky Pokemon, such as Heatran, Empoleon, and if not using Regenerator, RegenVest Pokemon such as Manaphy and Swampert. Certain physical wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao and Galarian Zapdos are significant threats to Great Tusk, so it appreciates a secondary physical wall capable of checking these Pokemon such as Corviknight or Skarmory.

Offensive Bulk Up.description: Impressive offensive and defensive utility combined with the ability to remove entry hazards cements Great Tusk as a threatening sweeper that also takes on threats like Ceruledge, Iron Hands, and Roaring Moon. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk hit Flying-types like Dragonite, Zapdos, and Mandibuzz, while Knock Off instead debilitates defensive switch-ins like Mandibuzz, Fluffy Corviknight, and opposing Great Tusk. Headlong Rush helps deal with Poison-types like Pecharunt and Iron Moth as well as being Great Tusk's best option against Fairy-types like Scream Tail. Scrappy + Rapid Spin grants Great Tusk hazard removal that's not blocked by Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Pecharunt. Scrappy also notably enables Great Tusk to turn Intimidate Corviknight into setup fodder. Hazard-weak Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, Ceruledge, and Ogerpon-H appreciate Great Tusk's role as a spinner; in return, they can help threaten physically defensive checks like Fluffy Corviknight and Deoxys-D, making it easier for it to set up. Due to its mediocre Special Defense, Great Tusk is forced out by common threats such as Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Latios, making specially defensive teammates such as RegenVest Swampert, Meloetta, and Manaphy necessary. Despite its fantastic natural physical bulk, Great Tusk is troubled by certain wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao, Galarian Zapdos, and all Ogerpon formes, making physically defensive teammates such as Intimidate Skarmory, Fluffy Corviknight, and Unaware Deoxys-D greatly appreciated.

Choice Band.description: Great Tusk's excellent Attack, good bulk, and powerful STAB moves that have good coverage make it a fearsome wallbreaker that can pressure common physical walls like Corviknight, Pecharunt, and RegenVest Manaphy while also being able to support its team by removing entry hazards and removing the foe's item. Knock Off hinders switch-ins like Intimidate Corviknight and opposing Great Tusk, while Ice Spinner snipes Flying-types like Dragonite, Zapdos, and Landorus. Mold Breaker bypasses Fluffy, allowing Great Tusk to pressure Fluffy users like Corviknight, Skarmory, and opposing Great Tusk harder, and ignores abilities that give Pokemon an immunity to Ground, which are typically used on Pokemon like Pecharunt, Iron Hands, and Gholdengo. Fast physical cleaners like Zamazenta and Roaring Moon appreciate Great Tusk's ability to pressure and wear down their switch-ins like Pecharunt and Corviknight, letting them clean the opponent's team once the walls have been removed. Entry hazard-vulnerable teammates like Dragonite and Chien-Pao also appreciate Great Tusk being able to remove hazards for them, though a secondary hazard remover such as Corviknight should also be used, as Great Tusk is unreliable at removing hazards on its own. Hazard setters like Scream Tail and Heatran also synergize well with Great Tusk, as they can chip switch-ins to it like Zapdos; in return, Great Tusk can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the opponent's team, further chipping them down. Great Tusk's low Special Defense and average Speed leaves it vulnerable to common special attackers like Deoxys-S, Latios, and Scream Tail, so teammates that can deal with them like Heatran and RegenVest Manaphy make for great partners.

Pixilate.description: Scream Tail is a good offensive Pokemon that takes advantage of Boomburst's high Base Power when combined with Pixilate to act as an entry hazard setter or a late-game setup sweeper. With its fantastic defenses, good defensive typing, and great Speed tier, which lets it outspeed the Ogerpon formes, Latios, and Terrakion, it can threaten most of the tier, notably entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Mandibuzz and common offensive threats such as Dragonite, Iron Hands, Galarian Zapdos, and Roaring Moon. Stealth Rock takes advantage of the switches that Scream Tail forces against Pokemon like Great Tusk, chipping down walls for itself and its teammates to break through them, while Calm Mind provides it with opportunities to sweep late-game once Pokemon like Iron Moth and Heatran have been removed. Wish can help Scream Tail and its teammates like Great Tusk and Iron Hands that lack reliable recovery options restore HP. Protect lets Scream Tail scout out Choice-locked foes like Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Roaring Moon and recover HP safely with Leftovers or Wish. Scream Tail has a hard time breaking through stout specially defensive Pokemon like Swampert, Meloetta, and Manaphy without Calm Mind, making it appreciate offensive partners like Hisuian Electrode, Roaring Moon, and Iron Boulder. Scream Tail is very susceptible to being revenge killed by faster Pokemon like Iron Boulder and Barraskewda, which makes it appreciate having teammates that can offer it a defensive backbone like Fluffy Corviknight and Skarmory. Scream Tail can also appreciate Knock Off users like Roaring Moon and Empoleon, which can remove items like Assault Vest and Heavy-Duty Boots from Manaphy and Zapdos respectively. Spikes setters like Skarmory and Deoxys-D have great synergy with Scream Tail, spreading entry hazards with it, which can help break it through RegenVest users like Swampert and Manaphy.

Unaware.description: Scream Tail uses its good bulk and great typing to be a superb Unaware wall, taking hits from boosted attackers such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Tail Glow Manaphy. It can also act as a Wish passer for teammates without reliable healing such as Roaring Moon, non-Regenerator Great Tusk, and Primarina. Calm Mind can be used in order to take on special threats like Zapdos and Deoxys-S, while Thunder Wave is an option to cripple switch-ins like Iron Moth, Gholdengo, and Ceruledge. Offensive Pokemon like Barraskewda, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao appreciate Scream Tail being able to take on Pokemon like Iron Hands, Great Tusk, and Dragonite while also providing them with healing. Scream Tail struggles with Ghost-types such as Gholdengo, Gengar, and Ceruledge, so having checks to them like Manaphy, Mandibuzz, and Roaring Moon can help.Teammates like Corviknight and Great Tusk can aid Scream Tail by removing the entry hazards that can wear it down. Finally, Scream Tail appreciates the presence of defensive checks to Chien-Pao, Ogerpon-W, and Iron Boulder such as Manaphy, Mandibuzz, and Corviknight, as it struggles to take them on repeatedly.

Choice Band.description: Slither Wing's massive Attack stat alongside its powerful STAB moves makes it a strong wallbreaker, pivot, and revenge killer, able to threaten common physical walls like Corviknight, Deoxys-D, and Mandibuzz. First Impression lets Slither Wing pick off faster offensive threats like Chien-Pao, Latios, and Roaring Moon. Flare Blitz threatens Fluffy users like Corviknight, Zapdos, and Great Tusk as well as non-Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, while Earthquake threatens Ceruledge, Pecharunt, and non-Earth Eater Gholdengo. Tinted Lens helps Slither Wing revenge kill offensive threats like Dragonite, Zapdos, and Volcarona and boosts the power of U-turn against foes like Great Tusk, while Sword of Ruin lets Slither Wing OHKO Deoxys-D after entry hazard chip damage with U-turn, OHKO Fluffy Corviknight with Flare Blitz, OHKO Gholdengo with Earthquake, and 2HKO Defensive Great Tusk with Close Combat. While more niche, Scrappy lets it OHKO Gholdengo with Close Combat while still 2HKOing Intimidate Corviknight. Fast cleaners like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Iron Boulder appreciate Slither Wing's ability to pressure their walls like Corviknight and Gholdengo, letting them sweep late-game once those walls have been chipped down or removed. Slither Wing's middling speed and only decent bulk leaves it vulnerable to offensive threats that do not fear First Impression like Ceruledge, Dragonite, and Azelf, making checks to them like Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Heatran, respectively, valuable teammates. Slither Wing is also prone to getting worn down by entry hazards, so hazard removers like Mandibuzz and the aforementioned Great Tusk and Corviknight are greatly appreciated.

Offensive Pivot.description: Sandy Shocks leverages a great typing, solid Speed tier, and access to entry hazards and Volt Switch to be a solid offensive pivot. Volt Switch allows Sandy Shocks to pivot out of uncomfortable matchups such as Meloetta, RegenVest Roaring Moon, and Blissey. Entry hazards allow Sandy Shocks to consistently pressure foes, with Stealth Rock being a notable option over Spikes to hit Chien-Pao and Ceruledge, and they synergize well with its STAB moves which naturally threaten common hazard removers such as Corviknight and Great Tusk. Choice Scarf helps Sandy Shocks to alleviate its unimpressive Speed, turning it into a potent revenge killer and cleaner, outpacing threats such as Modest Deoxys-S, Iron Boulder, and Cinderace, while Heavy-Duty Boots allows it to bypass entry hazards, turning it into a more durable pivot and not locking it into a single move. Sandy Shocks works excellently with powerful physical pivots such as Meowscarada, Barraskewda, and Roaring Moon, threatening common physical walls such as Corviknight and Great Tusk and giving these physical wallbreakers opportunities while forming a potent VoltTurn core. Sandy Shocks is frail and struggles to switch in against non-Electric-types; defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Swampert are all appreciated to help alleviate this.

RegenVest.description: Iron Treads is a niche RegenVest wall that offers valuable Rapid Spin utility, pivoting, and a unique typing that resists the tier's common Psychic- and Electric-type special attacks. Volt Switch provides pivoting while also chipping switch-ins like Corviknight and Manaphy, whereas Knock Off greatly reduces the longevity of defensive walls, notably Great Tusk and Swampert who would normally come in to absorb Volt Switch. Iron Treads is a pain to deal with for fast Electric-types, including Hisuian Electrode and non-Weather Ball Zapdos, and it can survive a Focus Blast from Thundurus or an Earth Power from Sandy Shocks. It also acts as a reliable answer to Azelf, Latios, and Gholdengo, threatening them with Knock Off while not being crippled by Trick. Iron Treads fits best on stall teams, providing much-needed hazard removal while relying on other specially defensive walls like Empoleon and Blissey to cover its weaknesses to common special attackers such as Primarina, Sandy Shocks, and Iron Moth. Iron Treads also appreciates physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Toxapex, as it naturally loses to some of the tier's most common physical wallbreakers such as Ceruledge, Chien-Pao, and Galarian Zapdos. Iron Treads can also be run as a role compression option on more offensive teams, as it can provide semi-reliable pivoting and Rapid Spin support for Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-H; in return, they threaten the Ground-types that Iron Treads struggles against such as the aforementioned Swampert and Great Tusk.

Earth Eater.description: Swords Dance, huge bulk, and a good defensive typing allow Iron Hands to become an incredibly threatening wallbreaker. Earth Eater allows it to set up on would-be checks like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Sandy Shocks. Substitute allows it to take advantage of foes like Empoleon, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao, which are forced out by it, allowing it valuable turns to set up. 172 Special Defense EVs allow its Substitute and withstand a Scald from RegenVest Manaphy, while 196 Speed EVs let it outspeed Manaphy. It is next to impossible to OHKO a full health Iron Hands behind dual screens, so support from Prankster Corviknight and Deoxys-S on hyper offense teams can help by allowing it extra turns to set up and letting it beat would-be offensive checks like Latios and Primarina. Iron Hands struggles against Unaware Pokemon, in particular Deoxys-D and Scream Tail, so teammates that can threaten them like Gengar and Ceruledge make for good partners. Barraskewda and Chien-Pao are teammates that enjoy the presence of Iron Hands, as it is excellent at trading itself to remove would-be checks to them like physically defensive Primarina and Manaphy, Intimidate Corviknight, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon. Strong special attackers like Deoxys-S, Azelf, and Latios can be troublesome for Iron Hands, forcing it out; as a result, bulky special walls like Swampert, Manaphy, and Blissey are appreciated by it.

Surge Surfer.description: Surge Surfer Iron Hands is a great wallbreaker, leveraging the Speed boost procured by its ability to outspeed almost the entire unboosted metagame and set up with Swords Dance in order to break though opposing teams. It also has a great matchup against a lot of defensive staples such as Corviknight and Gholdengo. Ice Punch allows Iron Hands to hit Garchomp and foes that resist its STAB combination such as Latios, Dragonite, and Landorus-T for greater damage. Since Iron Hands is reliant on Electric Terrain to function, it must be paired with a Hadron Engine pivot such as Latios or Sandy Shocks, both of which can apply additional pressure on Great Tusk; in return, Iron Hands can beat Pokemon that Sandy Shocks is unable to hit such as Landorus-T. Iron Hands is not a conventional wallbreaker, and it can struggle to power through teams on its own; therefore, teammates such as Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder are appreciated, as they can apply pressure on Pokemon such as Deoxys-D and physically defensive Great Tusk, respectively, which Iron Hands struggles against. Pivots such as Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos are also great partners, as they can bait in Pokemon that Iron Hands can easily take advantage of to set up, such as Primarina and Corviknight.

RegenVest.description: Iron Hands's great natural bulk and typing let it serve as a potent mixed wall and pivot, checking and scouting common threats like Gholdengo, Iron Moth, Chien-Pao, and Dragonite. Drain Punch provides a drawback-free STAB move with recovery, while Close Combat grants more immediate power, being able to 2HKO Swampert. Earthquake allows Iron Hands to threaten offensive wallbreakers like Gengar, Iron Moth, and Gholdengo, while Ice Punch can help to hit Ground-types like Great Tusk that can block Volt Switch and Flying-types like Zapdos and Dragonite. Iron Hands struggles with strong Psychic- and Fairy-type wallbreakers like Azelf and Primarina, so it appreciates partners like Empoleon and Mandibuzz that can help with these matchups. Iron Hands dislikes common defensive Ground-types like Great Tusk and Swampert that can block its attempt to pivot with Volt Switch, and it can struggle against particularly strong physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, so it partners well with walls that can handle them like Corviknight and Deoxys-D. Frail offensive wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Azelf appreciate Iron Hands's ability to safely pivot them onto the field and wall revenge killers like Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Roaring Moon.

Desolate Land.description: Iron Moth functions as an offensive pivot that can also opt to spread status. U-turn allows Iron Moth to gain momentum on switch-ins such as Manaphy, Swampert, and Meloetta, as well as Fire-immune foes such as Well-Baked Body Gholdengo and Corviknight. Toxic and Toxic Spikes allow Iron Moth to chip down defensive Pokemon. Energy Ball is decent coverage against would-be switch-ins like Manaphy, Swampert, and Primordial Sea Barraskewda. Dazzling Gleam hits Dragon-types like Roaring Moon, Latios, and Dragonite. Discharge hits Manaphy and Well-Baked Body Corviknight and can notably paralyze Well-Baked Body Gholdengo. Desolate Land effectively grants Iron Moth a Water immunity, enabling it to switch into Ogerpon-W, Barraskewda, and Primarina for its team. Pokemon with setup moves like Ogerpon-W appreciate Iron Moth's ability to bait in RegenVest users like Manaphy and Meloetta and pivot on them. Iron Moth does pitiful damage to RegenVest users like Manaphy, Meloetta, and Hisuian Goodra, so it benefits from special wallbreakers like Deoxys-S, Scream Tail, and Latios that can lure in and help wear down shared checks; they also appreciate Iron Moth chipping said checks, especially with Toxic or Toxic Spikes.

Physically Defensive.description: Gholdengo's naturally good offensive presence, fantastic typing, and access to reliable recovery combine to make it a staple defensive piece. Hex can be run over Shadow Ball in conjunction with Thunder Wave to increase its maximum Base Power while spreading paralysis to support Gholdengo's teammates. Well-Baked Body allows Gholdengo to wall Pokemon reliant on Fire-type moves to beat it, such as Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Ogerpon-H lacking Knock Off. Similarly, Earth Eater handles opposing Ground-types such as non-Scrappy Great Tusk. Bulletproof is used to negate Shadow Ball from Gengar, Hisuian Zoroark, and opposing Gholdengo. Gholdengo's natural typing allows it to use nearly any immunity ability effectively, so options like Water Absorb and Volt Absorb can also be used depending on the needs of its team, although these are generally less effective. 28 Speed EVs are used to outspeed minimally invested Great Tusk, with the remaining EVs being used to maximize Gholdengo's physical bulk to better check physical attackers. Gholdengo is particularly vulnerable to Dark-types like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao, and many Pokemon like Iron Boulder and Ogerpon-C run Dark-type coverage specifically to hit all variants of it. Thus, Pokemon that can take hits from Dark-type attackers such as Corviknight and Great Tusk make good partners. Gholdengo cannot check most special attackers, so it appreciates having special walls such as Swampert and Manaphy as teammates. Finally, Gholdengo can be taken advantage of and used for momentum by RegenVest Pokemon such as Swampert and Meloetta, so it appreciates strong wallbreakers such as Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos to bust through these walls.

Choice Scarf.description: Thanks to its high base Special Attack that's further boosted by Adaptability, as well as its usable Speed that's improved by Choice Scarf, Gholdengo functions as a revenge killer and late-game cleaner. Trick allows Gholdengo to punish common switch-ins such as Swampert, Manaphy, and Empoleon, allowing teammates like Latios, Zapdos, and Primarina to deal more damage and beat their would-be checks. Recover, while it doesn't seem as though it would fit on a Choice Scarf Pokemon, is the preferred option in the fourth moveslot, as it greatly improves Gholdengo's longevity and becomes quite usable after it uses Trick. Focus Blast is a secondary option that provides a way for Gholdengo to hit bulky Steel-type Pokemon like Kingambit, Hisuian Goodra, and non-Bulletproof Empoleon; alternatively, Dazzling Gleam hits Roaring Moon, Latios, and Iron Hands. Adaptability, while boosting the power of Gholdengo's STAB moves and allows it to bluff immunity abilities such as Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater. Gholdengo threatens to outspeed and OHKO fast offensive threats such as Latios, Chien-Pao, and Iron Boulder but cannot switch safely into some of them. Gholdengo struggles against specially defensive walls such as Swampert, Empoleon, and Manaphy, so strong physical attackers like Ogerpon-H and Iron Hands can be used to beat them, and in return, while Ogerpon-H and Iron Hands appreciate Gholdengo's speed control. Gholdengo appreciates strong physical wallbreakers such as Roaring Moon and Zamazenta that improve its ability to clean, as well as slow pivots like Corviknight and Manaphy to help Gholdengo switch in safely.

Hadron Engine.description: Thanks to its high natural Special Attack further bostered by Hadron Engine as well as its decent Speed, Gholdengo functions as a menacing wallbreaker with Choice Specs, while it functions as speed control and as a revenge killer with Choice Scarf sets. Thunderbolt 2HKOes physically defensive RegenVest Manaphy, Primarina, and non-Volt Absorb Empoleon. Trick cripples common switch-ins to Gholdengo such as Swampert and Blissey, while Recover increases its longevity and allows it to switch in on certain attacks like Boomburst from Pixilate Scream Tail more consistently; alternatively, Dazzling Gleam nails Roaring Moon and Iron Hands. A Choice Scarf can be used to outspeed maximum Speed Great Tusk, Chien-Pao, and non-Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, but Choice Specs is an alternative option that allows Gholdengo to 2HKO specially defensive RegenVest Manaphy and Jirachi and pressure RegenVest users harder. Gholdengo pairs well with strong wallbreakers like Deoxys-S and Primarina, as they are able to break down bulky walls like Hisuian Goodra and Swampert, allowing Gholdengo to clean up. Gholdengo also pairs well with entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Garchomp, as the Spikes they set up can quickly wear down RegenVest Pokemon. While being a niche set, Surge Surfer Iron Hands pairs incredibly with Gholdengo, as it requires Electric Terrain to be up for it to function as a cleaner. Gholdengo struggles to find opportunities to safely switch in, so slow pivots such as Corviknight, Manaphy, and Swampert are appreciated. Hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight are necessary to prevent Gholdengo from being worn down by Spikes, especially if it's not running Recover. Gholdengo struggles against Heavy-Duty Boots Blissey and RegenVest Pokemon like Swampert and Hisuian Goodra, so Pokemon that can easily use Knock Off like Manaphy and Magic Guard Roaring Moon make for good partners.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Chien-Pao is a strong wallbreaker, being able to blast through many teams on its own. Its high Attack and Speed combined with its good STAB moves and Choice Band to bolster its damage even further make it extremely difficult to handle. Lash Out can be used over Crunch to hit Intimidate Corviknight harder. Ice Shard helps to pick up KOs on weakened, faster foes like Galarian Zapdos and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon; it can also OHKO frail targets like Hisuian Electrode from full HP. Sacred Sword hits Dark-, Steel-, and Rock-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Garganacl. Chien-Pao can have a hard time breaking through defensive Pokemon like Intimidate Corviknight and Quaquaval, making partners like Ceruledge and Dragonite appreciated. Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo can be tough foes for Chien-Pao, forcing it out; this makes slow pivots like Meloetta and RegenVest Manaphy good teammates, as they can deal with these Choice Scarf users and also help bring it in safely after taking a hit. Chien-Pao's weakness to Stealth Rock can become a problem quickly if not accounted for, so entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Mandibuzz are good partners.

Swords Dance.description: Access to Swords Dance and a high Attack and Speed stat make Chien-Pao a powerful wallbreaker and sweeper. It also has a STAB combination that is resisted by few Pokemon; hits physical walls like Mandibuzz, Deoxys-D, and Great Tusk super effectively; and can OHKO many offensive threats like Slither Wing after a Swords Dance. Ice Shard picks off faster foes like Hisuian Electrode and, after some chip damage, Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Sandy Shocks. Adaptability lets Chien-Pao OHKO Iron Moth and makes breaking through walls like Intimidate Corviknight easier, while Magic Guard offers more longevity. Special attackers like Latios and Azelf appreciate Chien-Pao being able to threaten their switch-ins like Gholdengo and Swampert, letting them rip massive holes in or sweep teams; they can also safely pivot it in, allowing more opportunities for it to deal significant damage. Chien-Pao appreciates other physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos helping break through walls like Intimidate Corviknight that it struggles to deal with. Chien-Pao is also prone to getting revenge killed by Choice Scarf users such as Latios and Azelf, so teammates that can switch into them and safely pivot it in like Swampert and Empoleon are appreciated.

Physical Wall.description: Thanks to its incredible defenses and solid utility movepool, Ting-Lu functions as an adequate physically defensive wall. Ting-Lu can use Spikes for entry hazard stack team archetypes, which benefit cleaners such as Azelf and Dragonite; alternatively, Stealth Rock allows Ting-Lu to provide general support for its team and deal chip damage to Corviknight, Chien-Pao, and Ceruledge. Ruination lets Ting-Lu chip would-be switch-ins like Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Galarian Zapdos, while Taunt blocks recovery and hazard removal attempts from the likes of Corviknight. Whirlwind works well with Spikes and prevents setup attempts from Pokemon such as Dragonite and Earth Eater Gholdengo, while Protect allows Ting-Lu to gain additional Leftovers recovery and figure out what move opposing Choice item Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Latios, Terrakion, and Zamazenta are going to use. Regenerator is the preferred ability on Ting-Lu, as it lacks reliable recovery, while Magic Guard is a secondary option that lets it switch in more easily because it won't take hazard damage or poison damage from Toxic and Toxic Spikes, but Magic Guard should only be used if there is another Regenerator Pokemon on its team. Pecharunt greatly appreciates Ting-Lu's presence, thanks to Ting-Lu's ability to switch in on Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Iron Boulder; Ting-Lu also appreciates Pecharunt, since Pecharunt can check Pokemon that Ting-Lu tends to struggle against like Iron Hands and Zamazenta. Ting-Lu also has trouble with Spikes, so hazard removers such as Corviknight and Great Tusk are greatly appreciated. Strong Water-type wallbreakers such as Primordial Sea Ogerpon-W and Primarina can easily switch in on Ting-Lu and greatly threaten it, so Pokemon such as Empoleon and Manaphy are appreciated to counter them.

Choice Item.description: No matter which of Choice Band or Choice Scarf you decide to use, rest assured: Roaring Moon will be able to blast holes in the enemy team. A high Attack combined with the power of Sword of Ruin as well as a good Speed tier allows it to function as a potent wallbreaker or revenge killer, depending on your choice of item. Earthquake and Stone Edge allow Roaring Moon to hit Steel-types such as Heatran and Fairy-types such as Enamorus-T, which resists both of its STAB moves, respectively. Lash Out is a good option to punish Intimidate Corviknight. Choice Scarf allows Roaring Moon to act as excellent speed control, outspeeding and revenge killing threats like Azelf and Deoxys-S, while Choice Band lets it OHKO Unaware Deoxys-D and Galarian Zapdos. Roaring Moon struggles against Fluffy Corviknight and defensive Great Tusk, so partners such as Azelf and Ogerpon-H are appreciated; in return, it can threaten their checks like Gholdengo and Iron Moth.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Roaring Moon leverages its excellent offensive profile with Magic Guard to outlast its common checks and still put tremendous pressure on the opposing team with Knock Off, pivoting, and an excellent Speed tier. Some normally reliable Roaring Moon answers like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Fluffy Corviknight are prone to being worn down through the combination of U-turn, losing their Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots, and switching in, often through entry hazards, just for Roaring Moon to pivot out. Roost, combined with Roaring Moon's decent bulk, allows it to have a credible defensive profile as well and switch into weak or resisted attacks from the likes of Iron Moth and Hisuian Electrode. Earthquake is an option to hit Iron Moth, Kingambit, Primarina, and Iron Hands harder than Dragon Claw. Taunt is an option as well that lets Roaring Moon deny recovery attempts and entry hazards from the likes of Corviknight and Empoleon. Roaring Moon loves being included on hazard stacking balance teams, as it can easily remove Heavy-Duty Boots and pivot around to wear down its checks. As a result, teammates like Scream Tail, Ting-Lu, and Great Tusk make excellent partners. Roaring Moon is an excellent choice to wear down common defensive staples like Fluffy Corviknight and Great Tusk, making it a great teammate for Pokemon like Zamazenta and Iron Boulder to burst through opposing teams. Roaring Moon struggles with faster offensive threats like Zamazenta and lacks immediate power against bulkier threats like physically defensive Manaphy and Primarina; as a result, it needs reliable partners like Pecharunt to tank hits and either reliable hazard stackers or powerful wallbreakers like Latios to push through those structures.
