Dragon Dance.description: Due to its high Attack and Speed further augmented by Dragon Dance, Roaring Moon functions incredibly as a threatening setup sweeper. Iron Head provides coverage for Fairy-types like Scream Tail, while Stone Edge nails Mandibuzz and can bypass Fluffy walls like Corviknight. Outrage is used to deal massive damage to physically bulky Pokemon such as Iron Hands at the cost of confusion; alternatively, Acrobatics can be used to handle Great Tusk and most Ogerpon formes after Weakness Policy's activation. Weakness Policy can easily be activated by a weak U-turn from Corviknight, Manaphy, or Azelf, while Life Orb provides consistent damage. Applicable partners include Prankster Corviknight for its dual screens support and ability to pivot Roaring Moon in safely, and Gholdengo, since it has incredible type synergy with Roaring Moon, being able to resist Fairy, Dragon, Bug, Ice, and having an immunity to Fighting. Roaring Moon struggles against defensive Great Tusk, especially Fluffy variants, and Fluffy Corviknight. With partners such as Azelf and Manaphy for Great Tusk and Iron Moth and Ogerpon-H for Corviknight, Roaring Moon's biggest checks and counters become quite threatened. Additionally, wallbreakers such as Choice Band Iron Boulder and Chien-Pao can both physically wear down defensive walls to clear the way for Roaring Moon to get a clean sweep.

RegenVest.description: Roaring Moon's excellent set of resistances, great Speed and Attack, and solid bulk make it a serviceable bulky pivot without the passivity of other RegenVest Pokemon like Manaphy and Swampert; in particular, its great typing allows it to scout and offensively check and prominent special attackers like Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Hisuian Electrode. U-turn allows it to maintain high momentum, pivoting out of difficult matchups like against Great Tusk and Fluffy Corviknight and healing off any chip damage with Regenerator. Earthquake allows it to hit Steel-types like Kingambit and Heatran, which would otherwise trouble it. Roaring Moon tends to play aggressively, with its average bulk contributing to it being seen mainly on offensive teams; therefore, hard-hitting offensive teammates like Ogerpon-C, Chien-Pao, and Azelf enjoy its presence. Roaring Moon cannot safely switch in on strong Dragon-types like Latios, so a secondary special wall like Empoleon or Scream Tail makes for an excellent partner. Entry hazards severely compromise Roaring Moon's longevity, and its lack of physical bulk makes it reliant on strong physical walls to take hits instead; as a result, physically defensive hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight are nearly essential partners.

Swords Dance.description: Fantastic STAB coverage, a solid Speed tier, and good coverage options all make Ogerpon-W a force to be reckoned with, being able to shatter most of the tier's physical walls such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Mandibuzz after a Swords Dance. Power Whip packs more of a punch, letting it OHKO RegenVest Manaphy without a Swords Dance boost, while Horn Leech grants it more longevity. Knock Off lets it threaten Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Heatran, while Play Rough picks off Dragon-types such as Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Latios. Trailblaze enables Ogerpon-W to act as more of a sweeper, letting it outspeed threats such as Iron Boulder, Chien-Pao, and Deoxys-S, while Spikes can be used to help chip down Hisuian Goodra and other walls for its teammates. Ogerpon-W pairs well with fast cleaners such as Iron Boulder and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, as they appreciate its ability to pressure Fluffy users such as Corviknight and Great Tusk thanks to Ivy Cudgel not making contact. In spite of its solid speed, Ogerpon-W is still threatened by faster targets such as Chien-Pao, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Roaring Moon, making defensive pivots such as Corviknight and Swampert crucial in order to bring it in safely.

Thanks to its great Attack stat, its strong STAB moves, and Swords Dance, Ogerpon-H is a powerful wallbreaker that's able to threaten common physical walls like Deoxys-D and non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight. Power Whip OHKOes defensive Great Tusk at +2 and has a good chance to OHKO offensive Great Tusk, while Horn Leech trades power for healing and a guaranteed chance to hit. Play Rough threatens Dragon-types like Dragonite and Roaring Moon looking to switch in, while Knock Off has a high chance of OHKOing Well-Baked Body Gholdengo at +2 and hinders switch-ins like Primordial Sea Zapdos and Well-Baked Body Mandibuzz and Corviknight. Fast cleaners like Choice Scarf Azelf and Chien-Pao appreciate Ogerpon-H's ability to threaten their switch-ins like RegenVest Swampert and Intimidate Corviknight, respectively, paving the way for them to clean late-game. Ogerpon-H's middling bulk and only decent Speed stat leave it threatened by many faster offensive foes like Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder, so teammates that can deal with them offensively like the aforementioned Choice Scarf Azelf and Chien-Pao or defensively like Great Tusk and Corviknight, which can also remove the entry hazards that Ogerpon-H is prone to getting worn down by, are appreciated. Entry hazard support from the likes of Great Tusk and Heatran is also appreciated, as it helps Ogerpon-H KO foes like Gholdengo and Deoxys-D.

When boosted by the power of Rocky Payload and its Cornerstone Mask, Ogerpon-C is a devastating wallbreaker that's capable of threatening nearly the entire metagame due to the lack of capable Rock-resistant Pokemon. Power Whip is Ogerpon-C's strongest Grass-type attack, OHKOing specially defensive Manaphy and having a good chance to OHKO offensive Great Tusk, while Horn Leech can provide recovery if desired. For the last moveslot, Knock Off has a good chance of OHKOing Gholdengo at +2, Low Kick deals with Hisuian Goodra and Kingambit, and Trailblaze increases Ogerpon-C's effectiveness against faster teams. Other physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon appreciate Ogerpon-C's presence, as together they can overwhelm physical walls such as Corviknight, Skarmory, and Great Tusk. Ogerpon-C's poor defensive typing and average Speed means it appreciates slow, bulky pivots such as Corviknight, RegenVest Swampert, and RegenVest Manaphy to provide it with safe entry onto the field. Its Speed also leaves it prone to getting picked off by faster offensive Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, so speedy teammates such as Barraskewda, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Physically Defensive.description: With Regenerator, a solid defensive typing, and high physical bulk, Archaludon acts as a good physical wall that can wear down the opposing team. Dragon Tail phazes setup sweepers like Iron Hands, Dragonite, and all Ogerpon formes, and Heavy Slam hits Fairy-types such as Scream Tail and Florges. Alternatively, Iron Defense benefits Body Press's damage output and renders Archaludon's matchup against physical setup sweepers better. As Archaludon forces switches with Dragon Tail, Stealth Rock further increases the chip damage it deals to the opposing team. Rocky Helmet lets Archaludon wear down pivots such as Barraskewda, Cinderace, and Roaring Moon. Archaludon covers a variety of physical attackers such as all Ogerpon formes, Roaring Moon, and Barraskewda, but it is overwhelmed by offensive wallbreakers like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Galarian Zapdos, so allies such as Fluffy Corviknight and Skarmory are much appreciated. Archaludon also appreciates Pokemon like Hisuian Electrode and the Ogerpon formes beating Swampert, which it can't make much progress against. Archaludon has poor Special Defense, which makes it vulnerable to special wallbreakers such as Heatran, Iron Moth, and Gengar, so it appreciates specially defensive allies like Blissey and Empoleon.

Offensive Entry Hazard Setter.description: Archaludon acts as a niche Stealth Rock setter that scares away common entry hazard removal options like Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Great Tusk with the combination of Electro Shot and Draco Meteor. Furthermore, Electro Shot + Primordial Sea allows Archaludon to threaten to snowball at a moment's notice. Earthquake smacks Desolate Land Iron Moth and Heatran attempting to come in on Electro Shot, while Body Press chunks checks like Blissey and Volt Absorb Empoleon. Primordial Sea allows Archaludon to offensively counter Iron Moth and grants it a one-turn Electro Shot. Additionally, Archaludon's good typing and natural physical bulk allow it to take on Zapdos and all Ogerpon formes in a pinch, but it should never be relied on to check them. Archaludon greatly struggles with its lack of Speed; as a result, fast offensive pivots that can bring it in safely like Roaring Moon, Azelf, and Walking Wake pair well with it, especially considering its ability to force hazard damage on their switch-ins, like Corviknight, Empoleon, and Manaphy. Archaludon's low Special Defense and Speed cause it to be susceptible to special attackers like Walking Wake, Azelf, and Pixilate Scream Tail, making pivots that can safely switch in to them like Empoleon, RegenVest Manaphy, and Swampert good partners.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Iron Boulder is one of the best single-button clickers imaginable; honestly, the other moves are mostly decorative. Sharpness- and Choice Band-boosted Mighty Cleave has excellent power and coverage, notably 2HKOing Unaware Deoxys-D and OHKOing most slower offensive Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Roaring Moon. Psycho Cut covers important targets like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Swampert, while Throat Chop reliably beats Gholdengo, and Sacred Sword beats Iron Treads and Hisuian Goodra. Iron Boulder has an awful defensive typing and greatly appreciates being brought in by slow pivots like Manaphy and Corviknight; thanks to its great Speed tier, it can usually force out the wallbreakers that come in on them in return. Iron Boulder also pairs well with other physically offensive threats like Barraskewda and Garchomp that can wear down opposing walls like Intimidate Corviknight with it. Fluffy walls such as Corviknight and Deoxys-D are extremely difficult for Iron Boulder to break past, so a strong Fire-type like Iron Moth or Ceruledge makes an excellent teammate.

Swords Dance.description: With an amazing Speed stat and great STAB moves, Iron Boulder stands out as one of the tier's strongest wallbreakers. Swords Dance lets it tear through some of the tier's most common physical walls including Great Tusk, Deoxys-D, and non-Fluffy Corviknight. Iron Boulder has plenty of options as a last move: Sacred Sword helps deal with Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra, Kingambit, and Iron Treads, as well as Regenerator Ting-Lu; Throat Chop notably hits Gholdengo; and Earthquake acts as a midground option, hitting the aformentioned Sacred Sword targets and non-Earth Eater Gholdengo at the cost of not getting boosted by Sharpness. Iron Boulder appreciates offensive pivots like Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, as they're able to clean up after it has weakened the physical walls. Iron Boulder also appreciates defensive pivots like Corviknight and Swampert, as they can bring it in safely. Despite its amazing Speed stat, it's still prone to getting revenge killed by faster targets like Chien-Pao, Hisuian Electrode, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, making defensive walls like Corviknight, Meloetta, and Great Tusk necessary. Iron Boulder lacks damage without a boost from Swords Dance, so entry hazard setters like Deoxys-D, Sandy Shocks, and Skarmory are greatly appreciated, as they help chip foes into its KO range.

Double Dance.description: The combination of Calm Mind and Agility, which lets Iron Crown outspeed almost the entire metagame after just one use, gives it the potential to be a deadly setup sweeper. Stored Power gives Iron Crown scaling damage, letting it 2HKO offensive threats like Iron Moth and Zamazenta after one Agility and OHKO them after one Calm Mind with some chip damage. Additionally, it lets Iron Crown 2HKO specially defensive Garchomp and RegenVest Iron Hands at +4, which can be easily achieved by letting its Weakness Policy activate. Furthermore, with one Agility boost and after Weakness Policy has activated or Calm Mind has been used twice, it lets Iron Crown OHKO even Psychic-resistant Pokemon like Corviknight and Gholdengo and 2HKO most RegenVest users, like Manaphy and Swampert. Iron Crown is heavily reliant on setup moves to perform its role, so it is easily shut down by Taunt, can be stopped by dedicated special walls like Blissey and Chansey, and needs teammates like Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-H that can handle them. A dual screens setter like Corviknight or Deoxys-S is appreciated to help Iron Crown with both activating its Weakness Policy and setting up safely. Bulky Dark-types like Mandibuzz and Kingambit give Iron Crown a lot of trouble, so teammates like Galvanize Kommo-o and Iron Hands are needed to remove them.

Prankster.description: Pecharunt uses its tremendous physical bulk, useful slate of resistances, and Prankster Parting Shot + Destiny Bond to anchor defensive cores, pivot to dangerous attackers, and eliminate opposing wincons in an emergency. Prominent physical attackers like Zamazenta, Iron Hands, and the Ogerpon formes struggle to break through it. Prankster Destiny Bond allows Pecharunt to trade itself for an opposing setup sweeper or cleaner that its team cannot handle, especially since it can alternate between Destiny Bond and its attacking move to keep the effect active. Malignant Chain is the preferred attack for its wonderful poison chance, but Shadow Ball is an option for its higher PP and ability to touch Corviknight. Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred option to maximize Pecharunt's ability to pivot freely without the need to recover, especially since Pecharunt's removal of Toxic Spikes lets it support teams without strong entry hazard removal, but Black Sludge is an option on teams with very reliable entry hazard control. Colbur Berry is a niche item to better check Roaring Moon. Pecharunt struggles mightily against Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Chien-Pao, as it cannot even pivot against them, so sturdy checks to them like Corviknight, Skarmory, and physically defensive Manaphy are strongly recommended. Pecharunt is petrified of Ceruledge, so teammates like Well-Baked Body Mandibuzz and Eject Button Garchomp are appreciated. Offensive teammates like Deoxys-S, Latios, and Roaring Moon love the free switches in Pecharunt generates with Parting Shot and its ability to switch into their revenge killers.

Physical Wall.description: Pecharunt is a solid physical wall with a massive Defense stat and valuable Ghost typing that allows it to handle the tier's many strong Fighting-type wallbreakers like Iron Hands, Galarian Zapdos, and Slither Wing. Toxic is mandatory on Corrosion sets and has more consistency and PP than Malignant Chain, but Malignant Chain provides a secondary STAB option that immediately threatens Ogerpon-W and Ogerpon-H. Hex pairs nicely with Toxic and should always be used on Corrosion sets, but Shadow Ball grants a stronger immediate hit, especially against Steel-types like Corviknight and Empoleon. Pecharunt can safely pivot in frail offensive teammates like Chien-Pao, Ogerpon-C, and Sandy Shocks with Parting Shot, while also being a great switch-in to dangerous revenge killers like Barraskewda and Zamazenta that threaten them. Well-Baked Body allows Pecharunt to shut down Fire-type wallbreakers like Cinderace and Ogerpon-H, while Intimidate pushes its already tremendous walling capabilities even further, letting it act as a hard counter to the aforementioned Fighting-types. Earth Eater is another option that allows Pecharunt to handle Garchomp and Great Tusk, as well as letting it safely block the latter's Rapid Spin. Black Sludge provides passive healing, while itemless lets it wall Ceruledge with Well-Baked Body and take less damage from Knock Off Roaring Moon. Pecharunt is weak to some of the tier's common physical attackers, including Iron Boulder, Kingambit, and Chien-Pao, so it appreciates support from other physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Skarmory. Pecharunt's middling special bulk means that it struggles against the tier's special attackers, most notably Iron Moth, which it struggles to do meaningful damage against; RegenVest users such as Hisuian Goodra, Swampert, and Manaphy help cover these weaknesses.
